_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Applicable building, electrical, and plumbing codes. This facility complies with the Iowa Fertilizer Law.
_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: We utilize those portions of these codes which are deemed applicable by the jurisdictional authority
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: theft, vandalism; vehicular protection; potential leaking from underground piping
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Breakaway couplers at the risers and remote emergency shut-off valves at the storage tanks
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Regular plant inspection/Routine preventive maintenance & repair
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Pumps, pump seals, pipes and plumbing, valves, electrical and safety equipment. The breakaway couplers, pressure relief valves and hoses are also inspected and replaced as necessary.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE AT INNOVATIVE AG SERVICES CO., ELMA, IOWA:

This facility complies with the ANSI Standard 61.1 - 1989 requirements for anhydrous ammonia storage with amendments. It is our policy to adhere to applicable Federal, State, and local regulations. If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to immediately notify the Elma Fire Department (via 911 call) and request that it respond to the emergency. Incidental to the notification to the fire department, a call to the Howard County, Iowa Emergency Management Agency and the Iowa Department of Natural Resources will be made. If there is a reportable quantity (RQ) release a call will also be made to the National Emergency Response Center.

While we have planned for an emergency it is acknowledged that a real emergency will be unexpected and may very well be much different and cannot be ensured to duplicate what may have been planned. In reality the situation that develops may not happen in the manner in which it was planned. In that event what may have been planned will serve only as a guideline to follow.

The Emergency Action Plan for this facility describes certain procedures that are intended to minimize hazards associated with human health and the environment from fires, explosions, the sudden and unexpected release of chemicals (i.e., anhydrous ammonia), tornadoes, bomb threats, or other accident or acts of God which might occur on our premises.

The primary emergency coordinator for Innovative Ag Services Co., Elma, Iowa is Randy Roethler, location manager. His work and 24-hour emergency response telephone numbers are provided in the Registration Section of this document. In addition, the following individuals (with associated work and 24-hour emergency response numbers) are to be contacted in order:

	Randy Roethler, location manager
		WORK: 	(641) 393-2260
                Home:    (641) 393-2360
		Cell:       (641) 330-4147

	Mark Foster, agronomist
		WORK:  (641) 393

-2260
		Cell:       (319) 240-9081

	Tony Meirick
		WORK:  (641) 393-2260
		Cell:     (641) 229-5948

DESCRIPTION OF THE ANHYDROUS AMMONIA STORAGE/DISTRIBUTION PLANT AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED AT INNOVATIVE AG SERVICES CO.:

This facility is a bulk anhydrous ammonia storage and distribution plant. The anhydrous ammonia that is stored at this facility is distributed to agricultural producers in the surrounding area who utilize the anhydrous ammonia for crop nutrient purposes.

The system consists of two (2) storage tanks with associated piping, valves, liquid pump, and other miscellaneous equipment. From time-to-time throughout the year numerous portable nurse tanks may also be present at the site. The anhydrous ammonia plant is only operated on a seasonal basis (Spring and Fall). Full-time equivalent employee numbers were computed on this basis. At a maximum, the plant operates a total of three months (1/4 of the year). The FTEs for this company locatio9n is sixteen (16).

THE WORST CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS:

The worst case scenario is the failure of the largest storage tank when filled to the greatest amount allowed (85% of capacity), resulting in the release of the total volume in a gaseous (hazardous ammonia vapor cloud) form. According to EPAÂ¿s RMP*Comp Program (Version 1.07), the distance to endpoint is 4.4 miles.

The alternative release scenario involves the transport delivery vehicle pulling away from the intake lines into the storage tank without disconnecting the transfer hoses. The resulting release, according to EPAÂ¿s RMP*Comp Program has a distance to endpoint of 0.1 mile.

The system is protected from major releases by internal excess flow valves, check valves, relief valves, manual shut-off valves, and remote emergency shut-off valves. The loadout risers used in filling nurse tanks are protected by breakaway couplers designed to immediately stop the flow of ammonia if the line or a hose breaks. All of the main storage tank val

ves are locked when not in use.

Since this facility is located in relatively close proximity to Elma provisions have been designed to notify all affected persons. An evacuation plan is in place.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:

This facility complies with EPAÂ¿s accident prevention rule and applicable State and local codes and regulations. The anhydrous ammonia system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with ANSI Standard K61.1-1989 with amendments and state law.
In addition the company has specific operating procedures in place intended to minimize the potential for an accidental (and potentially catastrophic) release of anhydrous ammonia. Finally, Innovative Ag Services Co. has extended to the Elma Fire Department the opportunity to visit our aanhydrous ammonia facilities, to participate in mock emergency simulation training, and to avail themselves of specific anhydrous ammonia health hazard information and training provided by the company.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

Innovative Ag Services Co. has never had an accident involving anhydrous ammonia that caused death, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations or sheltering-in-place.

THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:
In the event of an emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is the policy of Innovative Ag Services Co. to immediately notify the Elma Fire Department and the Howard County Emergency Management  Agency to request that they respond to the emergency. In the unlikely event that the Elma Fire Department is unable to adequately respond to the emergency, the fire department(s) with whom Elma Fire Department has mutual aid agreements will be summoned. We have discussed this policy with the fire department and the Howard County Emergency Management Agency. Members of the fire department a
and EMA have inspected our anhydrous ammonia plant. In addition, copies of photographs taken of our plant have been provided (for referen

ce) to those entities.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

The plan is to minimize those hazards to human health and to the environment that are associated with accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. Employees working at the bulk storage plant make routine observations prior to and during transfer operations of the anhydrous ammonia from the storage vessel to the nurse tanks. In so doing they are able to detect problems that are readily visible and easily identifiable before they arise. This routine inspection identifies external portions of the system which may be under stress or about to fail. Repairs can be made before they become problematic. Employees are annually trained to recognize hazards associated with storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia. In addition to annual training for employees who have been on the job for a number of years, the company conducts training for new hires. This training includes classroom instruction, on-site training at the plant, and follow-up observation to determine the comprehension and understanding of the new hire. Finally, the company routinely invites local fire department personnel to visit the site. In the event that the local fire department requests assistance in training its employees on anhydrous ammonia the company cooperates fully in their endeavors.
